data.message: More often than not, it's a sign of unportable/obsolete coding practices (especially that int main was standardized 26 years ago now). I would stay clear of anything that advocates its use; there are enough standard conforming resources, that others can (and should) be ignored.

:D :D :D I love your conformance to standards, but the idea here is that the most important algorithms are implemented. I don't know what you mean by "int main" was standardized 26 years ago, but back in 1992 when I was coding on Turbo C ++ it was void main, and it stayed like that in the early 2000s as well. I understand the idea about standards, but believe me, there are Biarne books with void main :)

I remeber cause I had the C++ handbook amd there was even an older book about just Plain C, which is why here you have printf and scanf. Because this is an app that shows code to implement algorithms, I guess the main thing here is the naming conventions.  And if you're smart enough to be able to code all the algorithms, we can forgive you for using void main :)

Ahmad Fatoum you are right about int main : // The Hello world program.  // pg 46, sec 3.2, Hello, World!  // No guarantees offered. Constructive comments to bs@research.att.com    #include <iostream>  int main() {  std::cout << "Hello, world!\n"; }  // note that "return 0;" isn't required in ISO C++

this was code from Bjarne's book, but amazingly I have been using void main since I started to program in the 90s. Not that I coded C++ for 20 years, but even in Uni there was no fuss. Anyway, the point is, the algorithm implementation is too much of a benefit to miss over this small mistake if we can call it that

Well, I didn't expect you to agree but as you put effort into answering me, I will try it nonetheless :)
A good reference code, I would entrust a beginner with should:
- not use compiler extensions (especially not of an obsolete compiler)
- should not have security vulnerabilities (buffer overflows is the only thing I spotted though)
- should mitigate undefined behavior (out-of-bounds-access, division-by-zero)
- should be as portable as possible (Seriously, if every example ends with getch(), I doubt the author knows how to use a terminal properly)
- should be clean, neat and interview-level material (one example: no unnecessary casts; one snippet has a rare sight of a cast that actually hides a bug, that would make the program crash on systems where sizeof(int) != sizeof(void*). 64-bit Linux is an example of such a system; have fun debugging that)
- should not use obsolete headers, should not use non-standard functions in standard headers

None of the examples seem to satisfy the above points.
I just looked for easily spotted things and didn't follow the flow of the algorithms, so I can't say how it would be performance-wise.

What I can say that's not C I would recommend to someone. That's badly-written Turbo C++ for DOS, which despite still being used academically in India and some Arab countries, ought to die. Discouraging its use is a step nearer to that.

(And yes I do know standard-conformance is not always possible/needed. I use GNU extensions extensively at work/private, but at least I can justify it (embedded systems or other low level stuff) and I do know that some of what I write is not "real" C. 
Examples meant for a beginner on the other hand should be correct and compilable with any conforming C compiler).

Ahmad Fatoum great information, and yes it was Turbo C++ for Dos 3.0 then 3.2 then 3.22. So tell me, What IDE do you use over Linux ? and do you have a "good" reference imlementation that is this comprehensive? I personally would convert all the samples into Python and send it to the develper if and when I have the time, cause I mainly like Python. I still have this nostalgic soft spot for C and C++. Also, with your permission I can send these comments to the Author :) now you made me feel like this is more "bershamat qabl imti7an" at uni :)

I am using windows actually. Too much of a game addict to leave the dark side :(
I am not sure what you mean with reference implementation here, but a good C resource is http://cppreference.com. Quite a bit of it is also available in Arabic (http://ar.cppreference.com).

Freenode's ##C channel has a useful website with resources:
http://www.iso-9899.info/wiki/Software
Personally, I didn't have the need to use an integrated environment yet; I am quite content with VIM mode and + gcc/clang + some plugins, I might switch to CLion though when it's production-ready (academic free license, yay!). Other good options are in the link above.

And feel free to use what I wrote. I doubt the developer would care enough though.

But now I think, I understand what you mean with reference implementation. I got no idea where to get good C implementations of basic algorithms. Maybe Rosetta Stone? having a Wiki format should ensure not too awful code, I guess.
